content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been having a hard time sleeping lately. My mind starts racing every night, and I can’t seem to turn it off. It’s mostly because of work—I’m worried about losing my job and how I’ll support my family if that happens. My partner insisted I come here, so I thought I’d give it a try, but honestly, I’m not sure how much talking about this is going to help.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like these worries about work and supporting your family are really weighing heavily on you, and they’re making it hard for you to sleep. That's a lot to carry, and it makes sense why you’re feeling unsure about talking. What has it been like for you trying to manage those racing thoughts?

Honestly, it feels impossible to manage. The more I try to stop thinking about everything, the more I feel stuck in this loop of worst-case scenarios. I keep replaying all these “what if” situations in my head, and it just spirals. It’s exhausting, but I don’t know how to turn it off.

It sounds exhausting to keep revisiting those “what if” scenarios, especially when they seem to take over your thoughts and leave you feeling stuck. It’s clear you’re trying hard to regain control over your mind, but it feels like it just keeps pulling you back into that cycle. Have there been any moments when you’ve been able to get even a bit of relief from this?

Not really, to be honest. Even when I think I'm distracting myself with something like TV or spending time with my kids, those worries are still in the back of my mind. It feels like they’re always there, no matter what I do. It’s hard to fully relax or enjoy anything when I’m constantly thinking about work and bills.

That sounds really overwhelming. Even when you're trying to enjoy moments or distract yourself, those worries seem to keep lingering in the background, making it tough to fully be present or find peace. It's clear how deeply these concerns about work and bills are affecting your daily life. What would it mean to you if there was even a small change in how you’re feeling right now?

If I could feel even a little more relaxed or get a decent night’s sleep, I think it would make a big difference. I’d have more energy for my kids and maybe feel less on edge. I just don’t know where to start or how to get there.

Feeling more relaxed and getting better sleep sounds like a meaningful change for you—it could help you feel less drained and more present for your family. It shows how much you value being there for them, even while carrying all these worries. Would it be helpful to explore ways that might work for you to begin moving toward that goal?

Honestly, I’m not really sure what might help. I’m open to suggestions, but I can’t help feeling skeptical. It’s hard to believe that something like talking or trying new techniques can actually calm my mind enough to sleep better or worry less. But I guess I’m willing to hear you out—what are you thinking?

Thank you for being open, even though you’re feeling skeptical—that’s a big step. Before offering any suggestions, it might help to talk about what’s been working for you, even in small ways, or any techniques you’ve tried in the past. Is there anything you’ve found comforting or calming, even if just for a moment? Or, if you'd like, we can review recent step count, sleep duration, or resting heart rate data to see if they reveal anything about how your body has been responding during this tough time. Would you like to explore that?

Honestly, I don’t think there’s been anything that’s worked—not in a way that really helps. I’ve tried watching TV or scrolling on my phone to distract myself, but it doesn’t really calm my mind. And I don’t really track things like sleep or fitness, so I’m not sure I even have any of that data. I guess I’ve felt like none of that would really make a difference anyway.

It sounds really frustrating to try things like distractions but not feel like they truly help calm your mind or bring noticeable relief. It’s understandable why it might feel like tracking sleep or fitness wouldn’t make a difference—when you’re in the thick of things, it can seem like nothing will change how you feel. Yet, you’re still here, open to exploring possibilities, which says a lot about your strength. What do you think would need to happen for you to feel like something *could* make a difference?

It’s hard to imagine what would help, to be honest. Maybe if I felt like I was making progress at work, or if I could stop all the “what if” thoughts, then things might get better. Right now, it’s just hard to even picture what that would look like.

It makes sense that feeling more secure at work or finding a way to quiet those “what if” thoughts could make things better for you. Right now, it seems like the uncertainty is making it difficult to see a clear path forward—and that's a tough place to be. It's understandable why imagining change feels challenging. If you could take even a small step toward feeling more in control, what would that step look like for you?

It’s tough to say what that step would be. Maybe figuring out how to manage those racing thoughts—like, how to stop them before they take over. Or something that would help me feel like I’m doing everything I can to keep my job. But honestly, I don’t know if that’s even possible right now.

It sounds like managing those racing thoughts and feeling confident in your efforts at work are important, but right now, the uncertainty feels overwhelming, and it’s hard to see what’s possible. You’ve identified some key areas that matter deeply to you—your job, your family, and your mental balance. Would it be okay if the conversation explored small ways to start working on one of those, even amidst the challenges?

It sounds like managing those racing thoughts and feeling confident in your efforts at work are important, but right now, the uncertainty feels overwhelming, and it’s hard to see what’s possible. A small, manageable step toward either quieting your mind or feeling more secure at work could be a good starting point. Would you be open to trying out a simple strategy to help with the racing thoughts, just to see if it might bring a little relief?

It’s understandable to feel unsure about taking that first step, especially when things feel overwhelming—but the fact that you’re willing to consider it is a great start. Small changes, even experimenting with one strategy, can sometimes lay the foundation for moving forward. Would you prefer to start by discussing ways to quiet your thoughts or strategies to approach work with more confidence?

I guess starting with the racing thoughts makes more sense since that’s what’s keeping me up at night. If I can get better sleep, maybe I’ll have more energy to focus on doing better at work. What kind of strategy are you talking about?

Focusing on the racing thoughts first sounds like a thoughtful approach—it could help you regain some energy and clarity for work and other areas of life. One simple strategy involves writing down the "what if" thoughts in a journal before bed. Putting those worries on paper can sometimes help you feel like they’re out of your mind for the night. Would you be open to trying something like that, or is there another idea you think might work better for you?
